title: Riot: "Old game modes like Hexakill and One For All aren't compatible with the new client"
body:
Also Riot: "We implemented a completely new game mode into the client with a UI made of entirely new components!"
{{sticker:slayer-jinx-unamused}}

most of that is just windows 8/10 or games that were built upon proprietary software (like whatever it is for fallout 3 that was a microsoft product)

one OS will have fine backwards compatibility and then the next has a storm of problems

considering most fixes are EASY to implement (almost all of them just requiring a file be present in order for things to run...), it's rather sad that they pretty much just lie about that part (the modes ran on the new client...it was the new client that started glitching and causing queues to crash, rotating game modes not to show up, etc)

typically the complicated game fixes are where the source code has to be rewritten (such as for available memory (some games were programmed to take everything available), resolution (things made for lower resolution show up small if not scaled

however...what is usually not complicated...is literally just moving something.  The game modes were not written in the client...none of them are...they are loaded BY the client and then run separately

If they can make Team fight Tactics in about 9 weeks (according to them), then they can absolutely fix the old gamemodes in FAR less time. They just don't want to cause when there are other modes people play less ranked.

I honestly have no idea what you're trying to say with this comment

Your reasoning is this:

> 1. Old game modes could not be instantly ported to the updated client

> 2. That means Riot can't make a **NEW** game mode for the updated client **2 YEARS LATER**

Never mind that Riot *has* released random game modes on the updated client, or that a completely new mode is something entirely different then updating an already existing mode.

Point one isn't my reasoning at all. I *know* you can't just slap the gamemodes on the new client at all, I am saying that they look almost exactly like the base game, so why is there 0 effort put into them and instead we are putting all the effort into something completely new that doesn't resemble the base game (mechanically) at all?

Point two isn't even there all the way. Riot *can* and *has* made new modes in the past two years. I complained then like I am now. Granted that I enjoyed the other game modes like Nexus Blitz and Nexus Siege much more than I do tft, I am just confused as to why they jumped straight into making new modes rather than re-implement the old ones, whether that means build them from scratch or not. If I were making the roadmap for gamemodes the first thing I would say is "update/remake existing game modes to fit with the new client."

Also, if making a new mode and updating old ones are entirely different things, then why aren't they both happening at the same time, with different teams of people working on them?

I have no clue how your original post was seemingly so difficult to understand. Seemed pretty straightforward to me, but after reading these replies (especially this one) I'm scratching my head wondering how your post was taken so differently than it was written.

The client and League's game are, imho, two different things. It's like saying that when Apple released Logic X, which had a totally revamped GUI, it had to rewrite Logic 9's code from scratch: blatantly wrong. The client is just a mask, what Riot did was simply rewriting it and updating it, but I doubt anything, game-wise, has changed at all: actually, when the game starts, the old client's icon bumps up, alongside the client's new one. So, the story about the client "not supporting the old game modes" sounds like a big, fat lie. Of course there are elements of those game modes that need to be adapted, but it's a relatively light work because everything else is already there (the game's script, the items etc). 
Riot probably just tried to say that they were busy with other projects, like TFT.
